comments.commentBody: Mr. Sorkin is incorrect to say that those "companies" donated to Pawlenty's campaign.  In fact, the donations came from employees.  Some of these companies - Goldman, Wells Fargo, and Morgan Stanley in particular - have tens of thousands of employees so it may or may not be correct to assume that donations reflect the position of the company or top management.  Mr. Sorkin should correct this point, which is misleading to the point of bordering on inaccuracy.
I love your reading your responses regularly. You could have your own column. Sensible!

There are highly credible allegations-never fully investigated-that Israel "stole" nuclear technology and nuclear material from the United States to get their bomb. Does that sound like a "friend" to you?
Then, there is the "nuclear blackmail" issue from the 1973 war where Israel's Prime Minister threatened to "go nuclear" against the Arabs to force the United States' hand in the quick (and turns out decisive) resupply of Israel's military. This action, not in America's interests led to the OPEC embargo against the United States which destroyed our economy for some time back then. Was it responsible for Israel to use nuclear weapons as a "hammer" to get its way with the United States?

Read the facts on Israel's nuclear weapons. How they were obtained, used, and how Israel refused to sign the NPT. The facts are out there from legitimate sources for anyone to see-if the truth is wanted.
Thanks Laurie for the compliments, and the interest you have shown in my stray thoughts.

President Obama's General Assembly speech clearly reflects a statesman-like thinking that without being clouded by vitriolic domestic opposition to his Middle East policy shift, as well as the venomous and violent anti-US outbursts by the Islamic fanatics, could daringly move ahead defending the strong American belief in freedom of speech with a matching stern warning to the fledgeling Arab and North African democracies to respect that value by ordering their houses.

How are you so certain that this is failed socialism? Isnt it just common decency.What is the alternative? To lower wages to the point where men work as slaves for nothing? How does that restore the economy? The situation in Spain is more like a failure of the Euro to unify a basically unequal economically developed region. In any event is the solution to not help these people even if it is failed socialism? They at least need food, shelter, education and a means of returning to a society in which they can compete without failure.

what socialism are you talking about? Universal healthcare countries, like Germany or the UK, both example of communist countries ...?

Politicians make all kinds of promises, but this happens in Spain and elsewhere. It's up to you to wake up and learn your facts.

There were three Carlist wars in the XIX century. if your ancestors left during the first one I am amazed that your family stills remembers the fact.

Anyway, I am glad your family relocated to a great country. But this is not a reason to denigrate Spain. The Spanish history in the last 200 years has been not one of mediocrity, but of struggle. It takes plenty of courage to keep on fighting against the odds.

Seems to me that some of you are too ready to blame the Spanish people for what is really a worldwide depression caused by corporate greed and the world monetary system. Does Spain produce enough to feed itself?  My guess is Yes. What about the United States? I'd say yes there, too.  So why are people scavaging rubbish bins in both countries? Instead of condescending towards people in this plight , we should be redistributing wealth. Ken from Brooklyn talks about Spain's problems as "failed socialism."  The fastest way to bring on a US Spring, Ken, would be to go down the ridiculous Republican  track being held up as salvatiin by Romney and Ryan. All US politicians including Obama (one of the best ones) are far too influenced by the pressure of big business and too little by the plight of their poorest citizens. My own country, where I grew to adulthood without once meeting an unemployed person, is following you fast, aping your disgusting monetarist ways. My guess is that millions of Russians would probably agree with me. The EEC was never a good idea. Globalisation is even worse. Rubbish scavengers of the world unite.

Dave Lyons,

There are always some limits on free speech. Please don't equate the problems OWS protesters face when they push free speech protections to the absolute limit--for example, by taking over a public park, or by engaging in illegal behavior--with serious restrictions on free speech, especially those faced routinely by people in other cultures.

JMA,

What planet have you been living on? You are either deluded or a liar.
Please apply this principle to the Muslim clerics who routinely defame Christianity, Hinduism, and Judaism.  Does this give us in the US the right to burn mosques?
Thank you very much for writing and sharing your views with us.
And what was Bush doing do get Bin Laden between 2001 and 2009?  Precious little.
And isn't it remarkable that no Republican today seems to have either the brains or eloquence anywhere near that of the President.

I believe in Bismarck. Never let your enemy get so powerful that you can't defeat them. That is what we have done with both Iran and N. Korea. We have let them acquire nukes and now we can do nothing about them.

Geopolitics is a rough game, It is not about being nice to populations and feeding them when their government can.t. It is about using all the tools in the toolbox to bring them to their knees -- economic embargo, no visas, no diplomatic amunity, no aid of any kind (even disaster relief -- they have a disaster let them fix it on their own).

We make too many exceptions. We give food aid to the enemy, we give them disaster aid -- give them nothing. YOu must weaken them.

I would have aided Saddam in the Iran-Iraq war and ensured that he defeated Iran. That would have been smart politics. But we didn't We don't seem to have the skill to be a ruthless in weakening the enemy as we should -- unless of course you are talking about Assad - who never did anything to us and is none of our business.
Do you know about Bush the Unelected's response (lack thereof) to the words "Bin Laden Determined to Strike in U.S."? See http://www.nytimes.com/2012/09/11/opinion/the-bush-white-house-was-deaf-....
I'm surprised you can see democracy inside of Israel.

After having gone through a presidency in which two wars were started, torture was officially sanctioned, and the economy tanked, it is amazing to find someone write such a screed. You obviously have a visceral hatred for the president, but you have no credible argument.  By the way, what would you have the president do? Anything that the Israeli prime minister, who is an extremist, tells us to do and plunge the U.S. into another war-- with Iran now?
Obama was awesome.

Yes,israel is the most faithful and true friend to US.  Over a period of 11 years, Zalman Shapiro, an American Jew was suspected to have ties with Tel Aviv. Shapiro's appointment, 269 kilograms of enriched uranium was stolen from the American plant under the course of an operation conducted by four Mossad intelligence agents, Rafael Eitan, Avraham Ben-Dor, Ephraim Biegun and Avraham Hermoni.

Why is it that anything the President says, or does, these days the press comes out nonsensically with remarks saying that somehow it was done for political reasons in response to Romney, as in: 'the presidential election seemed to be a subtext.' That's not my idea of reporting. What does it mean for a reporter to report what he thought seemed to be anything. A pity the profession of journalism doesn't have higher standards.

h'mmmm--who would decide what constitutes "hate" speech? You? What if you and I disagree?

If you want to move to some other Western democracy that "functions better" (which do you have in mind?), you are free to do so, because you are an American. Go. And enjoy the stricter speech rules. We, here, like what we have, under our Constitution.

It's not entirely clear how "free" speech needs to be when it comes to hate speech, slander, and libel. Plenty of Western democracies function - arguably better - than in the U.S. with stricter libel, slander, and hate speech rules.

living in indonesia..make me easy to understand one thing: impossible to reason with religion. I could not understand how people get mad about their religion but in the same time ignore poverty, violence, killing each other. It may come from genetic, education system or else. So it is not all about america. whoever. May it comes from different part in brain...emotional side... like it or not we live in a world where many people put 'after life' business the most important thing...

Although I turned into C-SPAN late, I considered our president to be giving a sermon. Just how was I supposed to concentrate on his sedate points, when, as he was lecturing us, Syrians lie dead in their neighborhoods?  Hence, his speech was still yet another missed opportunity to make progress in reaching an end to this troubling civil war.

Not only we not in the 'mood' because it doesn't matter what mood we are in. My personal prediction is that there will be no war. least not with Iran or on behalf of Israel. Israel dug a hole for itself, a very deep hole and , at least, 70% of the entire world does not wish well for Israel.

its like living in some-one else' house and everyone in the house hates you and waiting for you to screw-up!! It shall be very, very ugly and unfortunately there is no-on to stop it. Not Israel can avoid what is coming. and probably not the hand of Iran either!

We are not in the mood to declare another war and we are not the United States of Israel.America is reeling as it is.We already supply $3 billion per yr. to Israel’s
6 million people, along with an abundance of war machinery. Where was Netanyahu’s compliance with ethical ‘red lines’ when our President called for a cessation of settlement encroachment into Palestinian territory? I hardly call Netanyahu’s demands ‘pleas’.Netanyahu has bullied, threatened and insulted our President on his own soil long enough and the rest of us as well..Our President is right to praise the great courage demonstrated and advances made by the Arab Spring in throwing off tyranny. To expect instantaneous procession into ordered peace exposes the naiveté of Mitt Romney to whom foreign relations are foreign indeed. (So, it seems are his constituents' domestic relations as the GOP just
blocked a Jobs Bill for Veterans and walked off the job to shutter Congress.)

After all,the President spoke at the ‘United’ Nations not ‘Divided’Nations.Let’s not demonize an emerging people based on the actions of extremists. We have our own 'christian' religious extremists,digging bunkers and arming themselves for overthrow. We are not defined by our worst anymore than are those striving for liberation from unthinkable tyranny.

The President is right in striving to harness nuclear energy for peace. But we must use every resource, especially our free speech toward for peace, not just our fractured atoms.
Israel, a democracy? No one outside of Israeli Jews and their supporters would agree with this statement.

My sentiments exactly!!! Hey, Israel is attempting to take over the wold, they can not do that unless the manipulate the American people. And believe it or not, many of the American people are just too greedy to resist them.

Me, I hope they get their war, then we will not have to worry them any more. There is no luck, and the cards are being slowly stack against them. And the United States, by the time they get there will be just in time to help with mass burial.

Yes,israel is the most faithful and true friend to US.  Over a period of 11 years, Zalman Shapiro, an American Jew was suspected to have ties with Tel Aviv. Shapiro's appointment, 269 kilograms of enriched uranium was stolen from the American plant under the course of an operation conducted by four Mossad intelligence agents, Rafael Eitan, Avraham Ben-Dor, Ephraim Biegun and Avraham Hermoni.

Kenneth Alexander: So you say Israel -- in other words, Jews -- is trying to take over the world? And you hope the country suffers mass casualties in a war? I like free speech exactly because it gives us a chance to identify and repudiate such sentiments for what they are: Jew hatred and bigoted conspiracy theory. BTW, the one you offer up about Israel's desire for world domination seems to be just a slight variation on what was written in the "The Protocols of the Elders of Zion," which, in case you didn't realize it, was a hoax .

Israel is a democracy -- yes, a democracy with a free press, free elections, independent judiciary and laws protecting minority rights. And while some express amazement that Israelis have the audacity to try survive in a region where their Arab neighbors -- in Egypt, Jordan, Syria, Hezbollah in Lebanon, the West Bank and Gaza -- have been trying to annhilate them for more than 60 years, I for one, am amazed at the level of restraint the country has shown given the fanatical hatred and aggression it faces.

As usual there are strong parental words for Iran, and no expectations demanded of Israel. While Israel is drumming up war and clearly intervening in our presidential elections we continue to tow their line that everyone in the middle east is a threat to the poor innocent Israelis. We sit on our hands while Israeli leaders lecture us on their own version of history, while they stockpile weapons made in the US for a war they want us to fight on their behalf. We are Israel's ally, but are they ours? When do we start demanding some respect from our so-called allies with the same thou-shalt tone that we use with our so-called axis of evil?

Thank you.  I can understand the nincompoops' reaction, but it's a shame when a tax law professor sounds like a KGB agent:  he doesn't know what the crime is, but believes that the accused is guilty anyway.

You can belittle the Bidens' charitable contributions; however, I'm sure that their tax rate was much greater than Romney's tax rate, and that is the bottom line.  As for class warfare rhetoric, it was Romney that made his 47% "moocher" statement, which he now says was "not elegant".  Finally, Romney's use of his Subchapter S corporation distributions, "as being nothing more than disguised compensation, "res ipsa loquitur".
Upon being asked to inspect a chicken, a Rabbi pronounced, "it is Kosher.... but it is also rotten!"

Doing what's within the law is not a dodge. There is no obligation of a taxpayer to pay more than they are required to. Following the law appears to be Romney's only crime. I guess he could have paid more taxes by reducing his $3 million of charitable deductions for 2011 (i.e. 30% of his income--a number I understand that as a percent of income is approximately 1000 times that of Joe Biden's charitable contribution for the WHOLE DECADE). I don't see Barry the Loser contributing anywhere near that percentage for all of his "compassion"

And for those with less of a legal mind might I remind you of Judge Learned Hand's quote: "Any one may so arrange his affairs that his taxes shall be as low as possible; he is not bound to choose that pattern which will best pay the Treasury; there is not even a patriotic duty to increase one's taxes." Judge Learned Hand, Helvering v. Gregory, 69 F.2d 809, 810-11 (2d Cir. 1934).

But then again, I guess I shouldn't expect that level of knowledge or responsibility from biased newspaper reporters who would rather succumb to the class warfare rhetoric instead of applauding success and encouraging people to strive for it.

Oh, sorry. Didn't mean to confuse the discussion and diatribe with facts.
